org.joonegap
Class NeuralNetManager

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--org.joonegap.NeuralNetManager
Direct Known Subclasses:
NIMNeuralNetManager, NoughtsAndCrossesNeuralNetManager, XORNeuralNetManager
public abstract class NeuralNetManager
extends java.lang.Object

NeuralNetManager manages the...

  • loading and saving (from chromosomes)
  • back-prop training of new networks (if desired)
  • cycling with input data
...of all neural networks. In this way, it is a one-stop shop for clients wishing to get hold of new neural networks and play them in matches, without worrying about their underlying genes or chromosomes.

This class is abstract. Clients must extend it and implement createUninitializedNeuralNetwork (to create the specific nodes/layers structure of their network) and getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt to specify some meaningful value for each output node in the neural net.

It is assumed that, for many problems, discrete values will be required from the neural net, and in many cases this is best achieved by having discrete output nodes (each with a specific 'meaning', such as a person's name in a facial recognition network), and sorting them by strength of activation.

If this is not the structure of your particular network, you can safely return null from getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt.

(note that all public methods are synchronized)

FAQ

Q: Ok, but what when 'getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt' returns 'null', as suggested by you elsewhere, for the neural networks having a 'continuous' output range?

Whatever value is returned by 'getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt' is, before it reaches the client, paired up into a MeaningStrengthPair (by way of a List after calling 'cycle'). The 'meaning' in the MeaningStrengthPair is whatever was set by 'getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt', and the 'strength' is the strength of activation.

For example, in a neural network designed to recognize people's faces, we might have two output nodes. The first output node might 'mean' a person Fred, and the second output node might 'mean' a person Wilma. Often in these situations, the clients will want to take whichever node has the highest activation as being the answer from the neural net. To assist in this process, the List returned by 'cycle' is sorted in order of strength of activation, so clients simply have to do...

String strThePersonIdentifiedIs = (String) ((MeaningStrengthPair) list.get( 0 )).getMeaning();

...even if the meaning of the nodes is just, say, an index value of some description, clients can return Integers in 'getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt'.

In cases where it is the strength of activation itself that the client is interested in, however (say for a XOR network with only one output node, where >0.5 is a '1', and <=0.5 is a '0') they can ignore this 'meaning' value altogether. They can simply do...

double dTheActivationStrengthIs = ((MeaningStrengthPair) list.get( 0 )).getStrength();
int iIConsiderThisValueA = dTheActivationStrengthIs > 0.5 ? 1 : 0

...in this case, they don't even use 'getMeaning' so it can return anything for all they care (including null).

Q: Is the Chromosomes' selection affected by this 'meaningful'?

The selection (or otherwise) of a given Chromosome is not related to the result of 'getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt'. It is decided entirely on the score as totalled up by 'gameOver'.

Q: Why do you sort the meaning-rank list?

Because, for many purposes (though somewhat arbitrarily) clients will be choosing the highest strength of activation as the 'right' answer.

Q: Why do you assert: "Sorting by strength is done largely 'behind the scenes', but clients will find the 'meaning' object directly useful." Useful for what?

It is normally the 'meaning' object that conveys what the answer from the network actually means, such as 'Fred' or 'Wilma'.

Parameters:
p_objIdentity - the identity under which this neural network was held when 'hold' was called
p_dInput - the input to cycle through the neural network
Returns:
a List of MeaningStrengthPairs for all output nodes

createUninitializedNeuralNetwork

protected abstract NeuralNet createUninitializedNeuralNetwork()
Create an uninitialized neural network of the structure you desire.

Clients should not set the network's inputs or outputs, or any monitors, and should not train the network in any way.

Returns:
a JOONE NeuralNet object

getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt

protected abstract java.lang.Object getMeaningOfOutputNodeAt(int p_iIndex)
Get the meaningful value of the neural network node at the given index. This value will be returned as part of a MeaningStrengthPair to your client. It is assumed that, for many problems, discrete values will be required from the neural net, and in many cases this is best achieved by having discrete output nodes (each with a specific 'meaning', such as a person's name in a facial recognition network).

When clients call cycle, JOONEGAP gathers the 'meaning' of each output node together with its strength of activation (for the given input), and puts them into a List of MeaningStrengthPairs, sorted by highest strength of activation. This is useful for many clients, who will wish to take the strongest activated output node as being the 'correct' answer from the neural network.

If your particular network does not use discrete output nodes, this method may not apply to you. For example, if you have a neural network for tackling the XOR problem, which has only one output node whose output is taken to be either 1 or 0 depending on whether it is greater or less than 0.5, then you are more interested in raw strength of activation than any 'meaning'. In that case, you would read the strength from the MeaningStrengthPair, and ignore the meaning altogether, so you can safely have this method return null.

Either way, the value returned by this method has no effect on the Chromosome selection process.

Parameters:
p_iIndex - the index of the output node
Returns:
the meaning of that node

getCustomConfiguration

protected Configuration getCustomConfiguration()
In the majority of cases, clients can leave JOONEGAP to create and initialize its own JGAP Configuration object. However, for fine-grained control over selection and mutation operators, clients may override this method.

Returns:
a custom Configuration object, with its natural selector, random generator, event manager, chromosome pool and all genetic operators set
